Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Communicate clearly and empathetically with patients and their families
Situation2: The doctor must deliver a difficult and serious diagnosis to a patient's family, who are understandably very upset.
Story:
I stared at my phone, my sister’s message glowing on the screen: “Don’t forget, we’re all counting on you to be there for Mom’s birthday dinner tonight.” I could almost hear her voice, full of hope and expectation. Family gatherings were sacred in our house, and as the eldest brother, I was expected to set the example, to be present, to laugh and share stories, to make Mom’s day special.

But as I slipped my phone back into my pocket, I caught sight of the anxious family waiting outside my office. Their son’s test results had just come in, and the news was not good. As their doctor, I owed them honesty, clarity, and compassion. I knew I couldn’t rush this conversation; they deserved my full attention, my empathy, my time.

My heart twisted as I weighed the two worlds pulling me in opposite directions. My family needed me to be a brother, to show up and celebrate. My patient’s family needed me to be a doctor, to guide them through heartbreak. I stood in the hallway, torn, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing down on me, unsure which door I would walk through next.
